##Japan's response to the new Crown Disease | a timeline

Micro signal

What happened before the Earth was destroyed?

Keypointï¼š

Infectious Diseases Act / Quarantine Act

On January 28, the Japanese Cabinet decided to designate COVID-19 infectious diseases as "designated infectious diseases" based on the Infectious Diseases Act and "quarantine infectious diseases" based on the Quarantine Act. A 10-day notice period was provided to consider the possible impact of the changes, which are scheduled to take effect on February 7, and was brought forward to February 1 following the WHO announcement of a public health emergency.

These two laws provide the legal basis and implementation reference for many epidemic response measures, and clearly regulate the collection and publication of information, health diagnosis and employment restrictions, disinfection measures and so on. According to the Infectious Diseases Act, infectious diseases are classified into three categories: Zaire Ebolavirus, hemorrhagic fever and plague, the new crown pneumonia was classified as "SARS"-like type 2 -- The government was allowed to investigate patients or suspected cases, arrange hospitalizations and sterilize their holdings.

Notably, with the diamond princess becoming increasingly contagious, voices from the Liberal Democrats and society are calling for Stronger Action; Right Wing Author Naoki Hyakuta has even written, calls on Japanese government to stop entry of Chinese and Koreans. On February 14th the ANBE administration amended its order to impose "quarantine" measures on entry that would force hospitalisation, as well as "stay-and-watch" measures that would allow suspected infections to be observed at designated facilities.

This restriction on travel has in essence gone beyond the response to Category 2 infectious diseases. Previously, although "Princess" passengers are required to stay in the ship's single room for observation isolation, but the lack of a clear legal basis. "forced isolation" measures had serious consequences during the leprosy epidemic in Japan, resulting in a large number of patients recovering from prejudice and discrimination. As a result, the changes are still subject to debate over whether human rights will be violated.

The water countermeasures are turning to prevent spread

On February 13, Minister Katsunobu Kato said at a news conference that Japan's current epidemic of the new crown "is not at the stage of epidemic spread, but it can not be denied that the spread of infection further. ". Two days later, he said the situation had "changed" and that new pneumonia had in fact become endemic in Japan.

This shows that this period of time, the Japanese epidemic has taken a major turn. As of February 12, all 17 people in Japan have been diagnosed with possible routes of infection. But in the four days to 16,29 new cases of infection, 12 people may not be able to identify the route of infection "community infection. ". Not only do they have no travel history, they have no obvious contact history, and they are spread over six different areas -- as if the infection had already begun to spread in the country.

In the early days, the Japanese government adopted an "aquatic strategy" that focused on border control: from raising China's alert level for infectious diseases to requiring arriving passengers to make health declarations, strengthening quarantine, and suspending some visas. But with the spread of the epidemic in the country, the Japan Society of Infectious Diseases and the Japan Society of Environmental Infections announced on February 21 that the epidemic should enter the stage of preventing the spread of the epidemic, that is, internal prevention and control.

The move has been criticized by some scholars as lagging behind the government's action. "My fear is that the government will think that the country is safe if the border is closed, " he told the Japan Times on February 4, "But what the government should do now is take early action on the assumption that there will be more infections in the country and that the epidemic will continue to worsen. "

In fact, Japan itself is not unprepared. On February 1, the Ministry of Health and Labour issued a liaison document to the prefectural health departments, requesting the establishment of a special "outpatient clinic for returnees and contacts" as well as consultation centers as soon as possible, a doctor's hotline was set up earlier. But in the face of a possible large-scale outbreak, the pressure of a shortage of medical resources is still a concern, a shortage of masks in the phenomenon has emerged in hospitals.

From February 11, the "infectious beds" outside the ordinary beds are allowed to be converted into a single ward or negative pressure ward after the admission of new patients with pneumonia. Japan has only about 1,800"negative pressure" beds for Class 1 and Class 2 infectious diseases, announced the introduction of a new influenza epidemic of the same standard of 1,600 beds, the number of 21 increased to about 3,400.

NHK NEWS VIDEO CLIP: Experts think the next key to Japan's epidemic prevention is to be able to restrain the spread of infection within 1-2 weeks
